channel.title: davewiner tweets
channel.description: A feed of recent tweets from davewiner.

item.description: Hah I got the Final Jeopardy question, none of the contestants did. To @annamasera — it required figuring out the Italian word for mercy.
I would like to announce at this time that I will never be the CEO of Twitter. https://t.co/cl9Q6BXSVq
I’m going to get a portable battery powered Alexa speaker for music listening outdoors. Got any ideas?
2022 Ford F-150 Lightning First Drive: A Monumental Electric Pickup Truck. https://t.co/LvQgU9ZK4q
“Democrats lose” — what bullshit. Everyone loses. At least now the enemy is on the record. https://t.co/q8KgirbtwM

We need to break out of the Democratic Party. They aren't taking care of this emergency. It's time to close the book on the Supreme Court. We will not be subject to Christian religion. We have to put a stop to this.
@jimkleiber following your idea where it leads.

Taylor's philosophy is the same as mine. When I started blogging back in 1994, mostly to the tech industry via the web and email, everyone thought I was launching an expensive newsletter. I kept saying no, I'm doing this because I want to get these ideas out there. That's all. https://t.co/BSZcOKMaoe
But I was flattered that they thought my writing was good enough for that. Soon after I started blogging I got an offer to write for Wired, which I jumped at. They paid me $500 per column. Still, I wasn't doing it for money. I just wanted to show people what was coming in tech.
Now, I *love* to make money. But the money wasn't in the subscription fees, it was in inventing something new and huge and then monetizing that in some way, and as it turned out, when I had a choice betw doing something huge or monetizing, I always went for #1.
Look at it this way.
1. You could create a new medium or
2. You could make Medium.
Sorry.
I just spilled a HUGE glass of icewater on my desk, the one with all the hard drives and umpteen USB ports and nothing shorted out and I didn't get electrocuted knock wood.
@noam @gassee Pretty sure he'll do exactly that.
Woodstock Library bond passes. https://t.co/z1wIzWm51H
@RobespierreX I don’t know about you but I don’t pick crops or was bentleys.
Democrats Are Sleepwalking Toward Climate Disaster. https://t.co/KdJVIxZPqK

If the Repubs had their way you and I would have no say in the govt and would receive no benefits. The govt would never build or repair roads, in a disaster it’s everyone on their own. There are no shades of gray in the philosophy. It’s a total oligarchy.
I would be surprised if we are allowed to remain in the country.
The Republican Party's attack on abortion rights is an assault on freedom. https://t.co/XFX5WK7ZDj
Alito’s draft opinion overturning Roe is still the only one circulated inside Supreme Court. https://t.co/Pi7Eb7dJQ3
Starlink review: How good is Elon Musk's satellite internet service? https://t.co/ZSNQ3MfrcL
Remembering Woodstock's Handmade Houses. https://t.co/eONtB10PfT
@KevinCTofel @sol I am pretty far out there! ;-)
@sol next door doesn't have a place for our town, or even the big city that's 20 miles away.

@jayrosen_nyu @AlexKoppelman they have panels of experts who are supposed to offer perspective. so the excuse that reporters are too busy to see the big picture doesn't seem right that's what the experts can do.

I wanted to ask a question on a local Facebook group about a construction project being done in town (the town the FB group covers). The admin rejected the question, suggesting I call the company. I find this sad and humorous at the same time. :-)

@cdixon I was a mac developer in 1984 and 1985 which were tough years to be a mac developer. When the boom came in 1986, we were virtually alone in the market, and we got a big share of the growth, and were able to exit, getting a great return for our investors.
